name: Negotiating Communication Preferences
description: This use case addresses the challenge of aligning differing communication styles and interpersonal boundaries between caregivers and older adults within ALFRED. It enables personalized interaction settings to balance caregiver efficiency and patient autonomy, ensuring respectful and effective communication.
scenario:
Elena Rivera eagerly activates ALFRED one afternoon, curious to explore new features that might help her stay engaged and connected. She speaks brightly, asking ALFRED to suggest a challenging exercise routine for the day, embracing the system’s ability to push her boundaries. She appreciates that ALFRED’s voice assistant patiently explains each new feature in detail, feeding her tech curiosity and enabling her to feel more in control. However, Elena’s openness to receiving all health notifications at any time contrasts sharply with the preferences of Mike Johnson, her assigned nurse.

Mike, juggling a busy urban hospital shift, logs into ALFRED remotely to review Elena’s latest health data. He appreciates that the system automatically silences non-critical notifications during his work hours, enabling him to focus efficiently on urgent patient needs. Yet, he quickly grows frustrated when ALFRED surfaces Elena’s preference to receive every notification immediately, including non-urgent updates and social messages. Mike finds such constant alerts distracting and worries they could impair his concentration during critical moments. He wishes ALFRED would prioritize clinical data access without requiring Elena’s explicit permission, but he is bound by the system’s privacy safeguards.

Meanwhile, Elena, aware of Mike’s working hours but unconcerned about privacy, has configured ALFRED to allow spontaneous chatting and video check-ins whenever she feels like it. She enjoys engaging with family and even random strangers through ALFRED’s social features, seeking lively, informal conversations. Mike, on the other hand, prefers scheduled video calls limited to hospital settings and avoids emotional or social interactions during clinical care, focusing strictly on physical health metrics. When an unexpected video call request from Elena arrives during his rounds, Mike declines politely, reinforcing his boundaries.

As the day progresses, ALFRED attempts to reconcile these conflicting preferences by offering Elena options to tailor her interaction modes, but tensions remain palpable. Elena resents any restrictions on her freedom to communicate openly, while Mike struggles to maintain professional efficiency without being overwhelmed. Their differing attitudes toward data sharing, communication style, and system control underscore the delicate balancing act ALFRED must perform to honor both patient autonomy and caregiver demands in real-world healthcare settings.
